nodes.title: Week 9: Other Sensory Systems, Attention, & Perception

typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the ninth week of the course!

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 5, Sections 5.4 to 5.6) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.

It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

nodes.title: Receptive Fields - Drag the Words (Liane Tang)
nodes.description: Drag the words into the correct boxes :)

typeData.textContent:
What is a visual receptive field? 
A visual receptive field is located in the retina, and is responsible for firing action potentials whenever the corresponding stimulus with the correct set of properties enters the receptive field. Ganglion cells are part of a visual receptive field.

What are ganglion receptive fields? 
Ganglion receptive fields are part of the retina and of a center-surround structure, which means that light falling on the center of a receptive field produces the opposite effect in comparison to when the light falls on the peripheral of a receptive field (Ranpura & Fitzgerald, 2019)

What is the difference between an on-center ganglion cell and an off-center ganglion cell?
An on-center ganglion cell will increase in firing rate/ the number of action potentials produced when light is hitting the center of their receptive field. Off-center ganglion cells, on the other hand, will increase in firing rate when light is exposed to the peripheral of their receptive field. 

Ranpura, A., Fitzgerald, A., (2019, October 09). Overview of Receptive Fields. Retrieved from https://brainconnection.brainhq.com/2004/03/06/overview-of-receptive-fields/

nodes.title: What is Phantom Limb Syndrome? (Bhavin Patel)
What is Phantom Limb Syndrome? (Bhavin Patel)
nodes.description: Phantom limb syndrome is the sensation of feeling stimuli in a previously amputated limb. The pain may occur due to the inability to relax muscles. By showing patients there intact phantom limb in a desirable position, pain may be alleviated.

nodes.title: Hearing aid
nodes.description: How would it be if you lost your hearing. No music, no sounds of nature, no listening to the voices of your loved ones. Some people with profound hearing loss do have options. Here is a video on Cochlear implants.

nodes.title: Week 9 Fill in the Blank (Malcolm Glumpak)
How sensory systems are involved in sensation play (Natalie Ho)
nodes.description:
Trigger Warning: Light BDSM topics, light bondage, temperature play, sensation play tools, mentions of spanking
Disclaimer: No graphic images or descriptions involving human beings or otherwise
Let's try to keep a sex-positive mindset!

typeData.textContent:
How does your sense of taste work?
- Tiny molecules are released when one eats or drinks food, in which these molecules stimulate the sensory cells within the mouth and throat
- These gustatory cells are clustered within the taste buds of the tongue and the roof of the mouth, and along the lining of the throat
- Many of the small bumps on the tip of the tongue contain taste buds
- At birth, individuals have around ~10,000 taste buds, but after age 50, you may start to lose them.
- When taste cells are stimulated, they send messages via 3 specialized taste nerves to the brain where specific tastes are identified
- Taste cells have receptors that respond to one of sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami

MYTH:  taste cells that respond to different tastes are found in separate regions of the tongue

Different types of taste cells are scattered throughout the tongue

- A chemosensory mechanism, called the common chemical sense, involves thousands of nerve endings especially on the moist surfaces of the eyes, nose, mouth and throat
- These give rise to  sensations such as coolness of mint, or the burning of chili peppers
- When one eats, sensations from the five taste qualities, combined with the common chemical sense and the feel of heat, cold, texture combined with a food’s aroma produces a perception of flavour


Many people think they have a problem with taste, actually have a problem with smell
- When one chews food, aromas are released that activates the sense of smell via a special 
 channel that connects the roof of the throat to the nose
- when nose is stuffed by sickness, odours can’t reach sensory cells in the nose that are stimulated by smell, then you lose much of the flavour
- Without smell, foods tend to taste bland and have little or no flavour

Different kinds of Taste Disorders
Hypogeusia - reduced ability to taste sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami
Ageusia - inability to detect any tastes
Dysgeusia - condition in which foul, salty, rancid, or metallic taste stays in the mouth

How are taste disorders determined?
- Can determine the extent of taste disorder by measuring lowest concentration of taste quality that you can detect or recognize
- Asked how to compare tastes of different substances or note how intensity of taste grows when substance’s concentration is increased


How are taste disorders serious?
- They help weaken or remove an early warning system that most of us take for granted
- Helps us detect spoiled food/liquids, or even the presence of ingredients  in which they are allergic
- Can act as a risk factor for heart disease, diabetes, stroke, and other illnesses that require sticking to a specific diet
- May cause someone to add too much sugar or salt to make food taste better, which is problematic for those with medical conditions such as diabetes or high blood pressure



*Thumbnail Image source: Harvey-Jenner, GettyImages. Retrieved from: https://www.cosmopolitan.co.za/health-fitness/coronavirus-symptoms-loss-of-taste-and-smell/

nodes.title: What is and Video Example of Selective Attention? (Bhavin Patel)
nodes.description: Intelligent behaviour requires prioritizing information that is relevant and minimizing the interference associated with irrelevant information. As a result, some stimuli may go unnoticed by the brain. This is known as selective attention.

nodes.title: Example of Inattentional blindness (Nicholas Mantegna)
nodes.description: an exploration of the phenomenon of inattentional blindness in an art gallery setting

typeData.textContent:
In Dr. Barnes lecture on selective attention, we learnt that we are unaware of what may seem like obvious phenomena in our surrounding environment.  This phenomenon called inattentional blindness is briefly touched upon by Dr. Barnes when he discusses the Daniel Simmons gorilla experiment.  After watching this lecture video, I wanted to find more examples of inattentional blindness.

In the article “An Artistic Exploration of Inattentional Blindness” Ellen K. Levy conducted an inattentional blindness experiment in an art gallery setting.  Levy created an animation where the audience was asked to count the number of times a certain card appeared on the screen.  In the background of the screen were antique artifacts that disappeared throughout the duration of the animation.  39% of the viewers of the animation did not notice the disappearance of the antiques.  When the viewers who did not notice the disappearance of the antiques went through the gallery again and rewatched the animation, 64% recalled the disappearance of the antiques.  Levy suggests that in an art gallery setting, the audience learns more and sees the same art piece from a different perspective viewed multiple times.

Recall that exogenous attention is a bottom up process and endogenous attention is a top down process.  Levy discussed that the second time viewers of the animation may have engaged in more top down processing, therefore allowing them to perform endogenous attention on the stolen artifacts.  Levy also recognizes that there is a discourse in the field of psychology on if inattentional blindness is a bottom up or top down process.  I found it interesting how much disagreement and lack of knowledge there currently is regarding inattentional blindness.  Levy’s conclusion about the connection between top down processing, learning, and inattentional blindness may fill some of the current knowledge gaps of inattentional blindness.  

Source:
Levy E. K. (2012). An artistic exploration of inattention blindness. Frontiers in human neuroscience, 5, 174. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnhum.2011.0017

nodes.title: An Experience with the "Gorilla Video" (Malcolm Glumpak)

typeData.textContent:
Would you look at that it’s already week 9, how time flies when you are learning cool new things; Especially in week 9. We are supposed to talk about things that caught our eye during the lecture or even during the readings. This concept however, caught my eye way back when I was in public school as a small kid.

	In week 9 lecture 4 we were taught about the basis of attention. That's how our sensory system reacts to increase in stimuli, whether it be voluntary or not. Now back to myself as a public school kid. I remember getting shown a video and being asked to count how many passes of a basketball the players made. So, me not knowing any better did as I was told and in the end wasn’t asked for the answer, I was actually asked if I saw the gorilla. “Gorilla?? What gorilla??” I said. Fully astonished that there was actually a man dressed up as a gorilla mid screen and I could not believe it. I found it so fascinating that one's brain could have such little attention while being asked to complete a relatively simple task. That was where I first learned the theory of inattentional blindness and it has come full circle to me now in university. 

	I found this very interesting and still use the theory now and again when multitasking. Since when I am trying to do too many things at once and miss something I know why. Furthermore, to relate this to the course content and what Dr. Barnes had in his lecture I explored more on Daniel Simons. His work best relates to change blindness and inattentional blindness, which is what we all learned in the fourth lecture. He is a cognitive psychologist who is known for visual perception, once again shown in lecture four in the gorilla video. 

Works Cited

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vJG698U2Mvo

nodes.description: Inattentional blindness is the failure of an observer to notice an object in the visual field due to being involved in a task that places demands on attention.

linkMetadata.title: Inattentional blindness – PSYC 101 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Inevitably, the phenomenon of inattentional blindness has created much discussion and debate amongst scientists and researchers. While still being explored and studied in more detail, such discussions have brought about questions such as “Why do certain stimuli catch our attention immediately while others go unnoticed?”, and “Do we still subconsciously perceive those stimuli that go unnoticed in our visual field?”.

nodes.title: The Gambling industry and its reliance on visual stimulus
nodes.description: A reflection of a application of stimulus

typeData.textContent:
Week 8’s reading involves the topic of signal detection theory and sensory adaptation. In reference to the textbook: signal detection theory refers to reacting to stimulus that is in contrast to current mental state and surroundings, and sensory adaptation refers to adapting to stimuli.

Both these ideas relate to each other in terms of explaining how humans react to changing or non changing stimuli. The gambling industry, mainly casinos, uses the idea of perception and changing stimuli to keep customers playing. 

Signal detection theory: 
Signal detection can be utilized primarily in slot machines. When one is playing a slot, players are often focused, hoping to catch matching lines of images. At this stage, slot machine displays are stoic, and quiet. Typically the only images moving are the moving lines of the game. This use of forcing the player to visually pay attention affects the attentiveness of their mental state, which is what the signal detection theory tackles. When a player wins a sum on a slot machine, casino’s often use flashing lights and sounds to notify that a player has won. Oftentimes, bright and colorful animations accompany the notification of a win. This contrast of slow and menial visuals into bright flashing lights and animation influences the player on the value of winning. Slot machines use the idea of visual stimulation intensity and its psychological influence. 

Sensory adaptation:
Sensory adaptation similarly plays into the idea of contrast. Compared to a home,  the ambiance of a casino with its flashing lights and sounds is naturally more stimulating. This over-stimulating environment is used to an advantage, as when a player returns home, the individual is forced to adapt to a less stimulating environment. This could make way for a sense of wanting to return to what they had adapted to, a high stimulating environment. 

Below is some info on casino and visual stimuli. 
University of British Columbia. "Casino lights and sounds encourage risky decision-making." ScienceDaily. ScienceDaily, 29 October 2018. <www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/10/181029130911.htm>.

nodes.title: Light and Sound Waves (Ricardo Liu)
nodes.description: see link

linkMetadata.title: Light and Sound Waves (Ricardo Liu) – PSYC 101 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Moreover, the amplitude of sound waves affects the loudness of the sounds that we perceive. Large amplitudes result in loud sounds, while small amplitudes result in quite sounds. The loudness of sounds is often measured as decibels (dB). Sounds that are harmful to our auditory system measure around 80 dB. Nonetheless, our perception of loudness is not only influenced by the amplitude of sound waves. The way amplitude and frequency interact with each other also plays an important role in determining the loudness of sounds. For instance, some sounds that are out of our audible range will be inaudible no matter how large the amplitude of the sound wave is.

typeData.textContent:
This week’s materials were focussed on the auditory system. However, it also mentioned the other chemical sensory systems in the body. One particular system that stood out to me is the olfactory system. Before taking this class, I had never given much thought to how exactly our senses worked. I had always wondered why some people preferred certain smells or weren’t as disturbed by other smells. Despite this curiosity, I never really decided to look into it. This week’s content helped me greatly in exploring how our senses work, in particular the sense of smell. I found the lecture that mentioned the olfactory system to be both eye-opening and intriguing. 
The function of the olfactory system is to send information about smell to the brain. Like many of the other sensory systems, the olfactory system also relies on its own receptors to convert physical change into neural signals. Although this sounds simple, there are actually several other factors that contribute to this. First of all, odor molecules first enter the nasal cavity and become trapped in mucus. The mucus then dissolves the odor molecules so that they can then interact with the hair-like extensions on the olfactory receptors. Afterwards, the chemical change from this interaction then sends signals to the glow glomeruli in the olfactory bulb. Once the sensory information reaches the glow glomeruli, it can then be carried to the limbic system and primary olfactory cortex by mitral cells. Finally, the sensory information can then be processed and perceived as smells.
I had never paid much attention to how our senses worked and always thought of them to function through rather simple processes. However, after this week’s materials, I realized that they are actually much more complicated than what intuition may make us believe. I had always just assumed that sensory information about smells would just travel straight to the brain. Although olfactory information relay does in fact follow a single pathway, it still requires many other structures to do so. Additionally, information relay in this system also goes through many steps, regardless of only following a single pathway. Conclusively, this week’s content aided me in realizing that even simple processes require many components to function.

nodes.title: Gustatory System and Taste Sensitivity (Scott Weber)
nodes.description: I discuss the gustatory system and taste sensitivity.

typeData.textContent:
Taste sensitivity is important when we eat any food. There are even people called a “supertaster” , which is someone with very sensitive taste buds (Holland). The gustatory system is the reason we are able to taste different things such as: salty and sweet and more. Our sense of smell and taste work together to help describe flavours. Smell and taste are both chemical senses as well. While there are extremely sensitive “supertasters”, we can have a reduced sensitivity due to environmental effects. Changes in sensitivity to taste can even happen due to our actions.

First, we need to understand how the gustatory system works. There are many taste groupings including sweet, bitter, salty, sour, and umami (experimental evidence suggests that we may have a taste for fatty content in food as well). We have roughly thirty-four receptor proteins in the gustatory system. Molecules from food and drink dissolve in our saliva and interact with our taste receptors on our tongue and in our mouth and throat. Taste buds are formed by groupings of taste receptors that have hair like extensions that protrude into the central pore of the taste bud. The binding on to the extensions causes a chemical change within the sensory cell that result in neural impulses being transmitted to the brain. Taste information is sent to the medulla, thalamus, limbic system, and gustatory cortex (Opensax).

The sensitivity of the gustatory system can be altered by many things. A short-term caloric deficit was associated with an increased sensitivity to sweet and salty substances (Zverev). This harmonizes well with conventional evidence we hear all the time with dieting. When on a diet and significantly restricting what we eat could lead to massive cravings. Another danger in addition to all the others when it comes to smoking is decreased taste sensitivity. “Smokers exhibited significantly lower taste sensitivity than non-smokers”. Continuing with    “the higher the nicotine dependency the lower the taste sensitivity score”. It is also important to note that stopping smoking does not lead to instant recovery of sensitivity and instead recovery time is “depending on sensitivity of loci on the tongue” (Chéruel et al.). This is interesting because it shows that things that we do may have consequences we are unaware of.


In conclusion the gustatory system is used in connection to the olfactory system to describe flavours. They are both chemical senses and that is because of how molecules interact with the receptors and transmit signals to the brian. I have learned a lot about how smoking and even short term caloric deficit can decrease or increase our sensitivity respectively. This section of this week's material was very interesting.






Bibliography:


Chéruel, Fabrice, et al. “Effect of Cigarette Smoke on Gustatory Sensitivity, Evaluation of the Deficit and of the Recovery Time-Course after Smoking Cessation.” Tobacco Induced Diseases, The International Society for the Prevention of Tobacco Induced Diseases, 28 Feb. 2017, www.tobaccoinduceddiseases.org/Effect-of-cigarette-smoke-on-gustatory-sensitivity-evaluation-of-the-deficit-and,69725,0,2.html.

Zverev, Y.P. Effects of caloric deprivation and satiety on sensitivity of the gustatory system. BMC Neurosci 5, 5 (2004). https://doi.org/10.1186/1471-2202-5-5


Holland, Kimberly. “Are you a Supertaster.” Edited by Alana Biggers, Healthline, Healthline Media, 21 Feb. 2019, www.healthline.com/health/food-nutrition/supertaster.

Opensax. “Chapter 5.” Psychology, 12.2 ed., OpenSax, 2014.

typeData.textContent:
In Dr. Barnes lecture on selective attention, we learnt that we are unaware of what may seem like obvious phenomena in our surrounding environment.  This phenomenon called inattentional blindness is briefly touched upon by Dr. Barnes when he discusses the Daniel Simmons gorilla experiment.  After watching this lecture video, I wanted to find more examples of inattentional blindness.

In the article “An Artistic Exploration of Inattentional Blindness” Ellen K. Levy conducted an inattentional blindness experiment in an art gallery setting.  Levy created an animation where the audience was asked to count the number of times a certain playing card appeared on the screen.  In the background of the screen were antique artifacts that disappeared throughout the duration of the animation.  39% of the viewers of the animation did not notice the disappearance of the antiques.  When the viewers who did not notice the disappearance of the antiques went through the gallery again and rewatched the animation, 64% recalled the disappearance of the antiques.  Levy suggests that in an art gallery setting, the audience learns more and sees the same art piece from a different perspective when viewed multiple times.

Recall that exogenous attention is a bottom up process and endogenous attention is a top down process.  Levy discussed that the second time viewers of the animation may have engaged in more top down processing, therefore allowing them to perform endogenous attention on the stolen artifacts.  Levy also recognizes that there is a discourse in the field of psychology on if inattentional blindness is a bottom up or top down process.  I found it interesting how much disagreement and lack of knowledge there currently is regarding inattentional blindness.  Levy’s conclusion about the connection between top down processing, learning, and inattentional blindness may fill some of the current knowledge gaps of inattentional blindness.

nodes.title: Path of a Neural Signal through the Visual System (Alex Barber-Cross)
nodes.description: Describes the path of a neural signal from a photoreceptor to the primary visual cortex with some concept check questions along the way. Connects to "Path of Light through the Visual System (Heather Cathcart)".

typeData.textContent:
The retina geniculate-striate system is a complex system that brings information taken from the eyes to be processed by the brain. Information taken from our eyes to our nasal retina (retina on the side of your nose) is brought to the lateral geniculate nucleus on the opposite hemisphere. After, it gets sent to the contralateral primary visual cortex for the brain to interpret the image. So for example, if something is triggered on the left vision field, the left nasal retina will send the signal to the right lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) which sends it to the right primary visual cortex. On the other hand, if the right visual field stimulates the temporal retina (retina on the side of your temples), it will send the signal to the ipsilateral LGN, to the primary visual cortex.. In other words, the signal would stay on one hemisphere of the brain. The retina geniculate-striate system has a pattern of cell networking; photoreceptors, bipolar cells, ganglion cells. This whole process can be extremely extensive, and learning how the different types of cells communicate is also tricky. A Marshall 1949 article shows that cats respond extremely well to both ipsilateral and contralateral stimuli. However, there is some evidence to show that it would be extremely different if asphyxia was a factor.

References
Marshall, W. H. (1949, January 3). EXCITABILITY CYCLE AND INTERACTION IN GENICULATE-STRIATE SYSTEM OF CAT*. Retrieved from https://journals.physiology.org/doi/pdf/10.1152/jn.1949.12.4.277

nodes.title: Higher Visual Cortices and Agnosia Presentation (Tina Zhang)
The Evolution of Colour Vision (Michael Choi)
nodes.description: Extension of Colour Vision node on the "evolution of colour vision."

typeData.textContent:
Evolution has had a great impact on the mechanisms of colour perception. This is often correlated with the evolution of having to recognize proper food sources and survival. We can see the evidence based on the evolution of colour vision in herbivores, primates, and nocturnals specifically. Studying how light and colour create a unique perception of identifying food for all species helps to create a better understanding of how our eyes have developed in order to perceive colour for survival. 

The colour vision of herbivores have evolved around the essential need to find the proper leaves or flowers to feed on. For example, hummingbirds rely on their ability to identify the particular colours of flowers to know their targets. Most herbivores do not see colours in the trichromatic ways humans have evolved to perceive colour. Rather, many herbivores possess the dichromatic vision as they are able to distinguish the colourful plants apart from the green leaves. Unlike the herbivores, nocturnals have developed in a different fashion in term of eyesight and colour vision

Nocturnal animals’ eyesights have evolved with less-developed colour vision, however it attracts the adequate light necessary to function to find food during darker nights. This allows environments that may be pitch black to primates, be “dim” lighting for nocturnal animals. Due to having to see in such dark conditions, nocturnals possess big eyes that contain many more rods that can help sense very dim, scattered lights that do not process a coloured images the same way having many cones in their eyes would. This contrasts the evolution of the trichromatic vision that most primates have evolved into using.

	In terms of primates such as monkeys, apes, and of course humans, we have evolved into diurnal (daytime) eye activity to help us identify foods such as fruits and leaves. The early primates’ transition into diurnal activities allowed the development of the highly advantageous trichromatic colour vision that allowed for identification of finding fruit (as the “fruit theory” stated in the past), and the adaptability to survive in daylight by perceiving accurate colour vision.

	In the end, the evidence shows that the evolution of colour vision has revolved around the idea of survival, which translates into the need to find food sources. As nocturnal bats differ from omnivorous humans, who differ from herbivorous deers, the necessary perception of light and colour has caused the eyes of different species to evolve in different formations and theoretical methods (eg. trichromatic theory) in order for survival.

Bibliography

https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-42096-7_8

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_vision#:~:text=Color%20vision%20is%20an%20ability,distributions)%20independently%20of%20light%20intensity.

https://northernwoodlands.org/outside_story/article/night-vision-how-animals-see

linkMetadata.title: W8: Color Vision (Karat Wannissorn) – PSYC 101 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: An example of colour constancy is in the image of strawberries below. The strawberries are illuminated with blue light and are objectively grey. However, a lot of people see red, since our brain considers the context of the picture. (Strawberries are typically red, so they are constantly perceived as red.) This theory also proves that colour is a psychophysical property, not totally physical.

nodes.title: Properties of Waves and Color Vision (Wesley Lam)
nodes.description: Fill in the blanks, be careful for wrong answers!

typeData.textContent: Our group tapestry contributions from the group "Oranges". Here, we're going to situate some of the content we learned about in the Week 8 readings and lectures in the context of colour vision.

Colour blindness is a condition in which an individual does not perceive colour in the way other people due. First, to understand why some people are unable to see colour the same way others can, we need to review how colour vision works in the first place.

	Colour vision is a trait that many animals possess and it has a variety of uses, including object detection and object discrimination. In the human retina, there are rods and cones, which are receptors that work together in order for the brain to form an image. There are three different types of of cones, or photoreceptors, that detect colour: S cones, M cones, and L cones. The S cone detects  short wavelengths of  light, like the colour blue, M cones detect medium wavelengths, like the colour green, and L cones detect long wavelengths, like the colour red. These cone cells are located in the fovea, an area in the retina, and work best in bright conditions. We see more than just red, green and blue, which can be explained by the opponent colour theory, which is the theory that 3 mechanisms are responsible for the perception of colour, the opponency being between red and green, blue and yellow, and black and white. Then all visual visual information from the rods and cones are sent through the optic nerve in the back of the eye and is sent to the brain, which allows you to see shapes and colours.

	So why can’t some people see colour? Well, often times it is not that people cannot see colour at all, which is possible, but sometimes it is that people find it difficult to distinguish between certain colours. There are three major types of colour blindness: red-green colour blindness, blue-yellow colour blindness, and complete colour blindness. Red-green colour blindness results in the individual having difficulty distinguishing red and green, blue-yellow colour blindness means the person has trouble distinguishing between red from yellow and blue from green, and complete colour blindness means the person cannot see colour at all. Most commonly, colour blindness is caused by some or all of the cones missing in the retina, which is typically a condition that people are born with. The type of colourblindness is caused by the type of cones that are missing. The effects of colour blindness can also be made worse in lower lighting because cones work best in bright conditions. 






National Eye Institute. (2019). Types of Color Blindness. Retrieved from: https://www.nei.nih.gov/learn-about-eye-health/eye-conditions-and-diseases/color-blindness/types-color-blindness

Turbert, D. (2019). What Are he Symptoms and Causes of Color Blindness?. Retrieved from: https://www.aao.org/eye-health/diseases/color-blindness-symptoms

nodes.title: How do we see colour? (Sarah Jiang)
nodes.description: A quick recap of how light travels through and interacts with our eyes to allow us to perceive colour!

nodes.title: Parts of the Eye and Colour Blindness (Lindsay Anta)

typeData.textContent: Parts

CONES:
Our cones are the photoreceptor cells within our eyes which detect light and are very sensitive
to detail, and provide tremendous spatial resolution. Normally, humans have three color vision
cones and each of these cones is maximally sensitive to a slightly different wavelength of light.
Cone pigments generally have different levels of absorbance. These cones all work together to
allow us to perceive colour.
Cones are located in the back of the eye area known as the fovea, which is part of the retina
(light sensitive lining of eye).

TRICHROMATIC THEORY OF COLOUR VISION:
This colour vision theory is also known as the Young-Helmholtz theory of color vision because it
was initially proposed by Thomas Young and then later developed by Herman Von Helmholtz.
This is the earliest colour vision theory and is yet still very well known.
This theory was first proposed by Young in 1802 when he proposed that colour results from
the combined result of the three different receptor cones and that each receptor cone is sensitive
to a different range of wavelengths of light.
This was then later developed by Helmholtz in the mid 1800s where he expanded on Young’s
idea of colour vision. He proposed that the strength of the colour signal absorbed by the cones
determined how one would interpret color in one’s environment. He proposed that cones were
either short(~440nm), medium(~535nm), or long(~565nm) wavelength sensitive and each
corresponded to the colours blue, green, and red, respectively.
Helmholtz managed to determine this through an experiment and explained that normal
color vision requires the absorption of three wavelengths of light to create different
colours. Initially, he used color matching experiments where participants would alter the
amounts of three wavelengths of light to match a test colour. Then when participants would try
to match the test colour when given two wavelengths to alter, they were unable to do so. This
supported the trichromatic color theory, which would also then be known as the Young-
Helmholtz theory of color vision.
This theory explains how the outputs from the three cones combined for a single colour’s
wavelength absorbed would result in a single colour that that cannot be confused for any other
single wavelength.

COLOUR VISION:
Color perception is incredibly important in our day to day lives. It can affect mood,
interpretations of the environment and can also stand for symbols within this world. It is
known through research that we are able to distinguish as many as 7 million different colours.
This perception of color is possible through the input of our photoreceptors cells also known as
cones, which are found densely packed within the fovea. There are multiple colour vision
theories such as the trichromatic theory of colour vision (which we discussed) and opponent
color theories. All these theories discuss our perception of colour vision.




References:

Barnes, S. (2020). Week 8, Lecture 5: Color Vision [Lecture Video PowerPoint]. Retrieved from Canvas

Cherry, Kendra. “Verywell mind”. The Trichromatic Theory of Color Vision, Kendra Cherry, 2020,
www.verywellmind.com/what-is-the-trichromatic-theory-of-color-vision-2795831. Accessed 22
July 2020

July 2020
